prompt.p: Monocytes and macrophages are types of leucocytes (white cells).
What percentage of circulating white cells are represented by monocytes?

modalFeedback.p: Option D (5%) is Correct. Monocytes are larger than neutrophils and make up around 5% of circulating white cells. The nucleus is characteristically kidney-shaped (indented), with vacuoles within the cytoplasm. Monocytes contain granules that store acid hydrolases and myeloperoxidase. Monocytes and macrophages can ingest pathogenic material; degrade it and present peptides or peptide fragments to T lymphocytes. Because of this function, monocytes and macrophages are called antigen-presenting cells , since they present antigen to T cells. Monocytes circulate for about 10 h in the blood before they mature into tissue macrophages. Their main role is to kill intracellular microorganisms, such as Listeria , mycobacteria and some fungi.
Option A (50–70%) is Incorrect. Monocytes make up about 5% of circulating white cells.
Option B (20–40%) is Incorrect. Monocytes make up about 5% of circulating white cells.
Option C (25%) is Incorrect. Monocytes make up about 5% of circulating white cells.
Option E (0.2%) is Incorrect. Monocytes make up about 5% of circulating white cells.
